poem:
In the Theatre of the Brontës

Under the shadow of the moor,
Three sisters with a forgotten brother,
Stirring bouts as in old folklore,
Unseen pain, they hide from mother.

Kard's spectacle, in light arrayed,
Amid the glare, their feuds we perceive,
But Brontës' strife, in darkness played,
Yet, their genius in silence weave.

In quiet corners, words in air flit,
More than backbites, the pen is their hit.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Wuthering fights: the play that shows the Brontës were bigger backstabbers than the Kardashians Natalie Ibu is about to make her National Theatre debut directing a new play about the Brontë sisters, but the Kardashians keep creeping in. “I’m constantly comparing them, because they’re the ultimate disruptors – and they’re also three sisters with a brother that no one really remembers. We may not like what they stand for, but they are successful and exquisite". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Wuthering fights: the play that shows the Brontës were bigger backstabbers than the Kardashians Natalie Ibu is about to make her National Theatre debut directing a new play about the Brontë sisters, but the Kardashians keep creeping in. “I’m constantly comparing them, because they’re the ultimate disruptors – and they’re also three sisters with a brother that no one really remembers. We may not like what they stand for, but they are successful and exquisite
